newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Survey reveals catalogue of trade barriers for EU.
newsitem.headline: Survey reveals catalogue of trade barriers for EU.

text.p: European Union companies face a maze of problems ranging from corruption to poor accounting when trading with non-EU countries, a survey by a leading business group shows.

An examination of non-tariff barriers by the Association of European Chambers of Commerce (Eurochambers) shows over a third of companies questioned experienced "significant problems" while trading with third countries.
"Things have improved over the last few years but the study shows that problems remain," Hylko Oosterloo, a Eurochambers official told Reuters.
Although Oosterloo conceded the survey was not scientific, he said it was a useful exercise in gauging the range and type of hurdles that EU businesses face in trade outside the 15-nation bloc.

Some 700 companies were polled to find out how easy it was for them to do business with a range of non-EU countries. Belgian firms, for example, were asked about their relations with Israel; Spain with Colombia and Sweden with China.
"The examples provided by this study show that many trade barriers persist worldwide," Oosterloo said. "We hope that by highlighting the problems, efforts can be made to eliminate them."
Eurochambers has presented the results of its survey to the European Commission to include in wider studies of trade barriers.

The group has also made a series of recommendations to Trade Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan, urging less interference as well as calling for the EU not to resort to retaliation as a means of solving disputes.
Eurochambers was also critical of some Commission trade moves and derided its "key niche market policy" as being meaningless.

The Commission said earlier this year that it wanted to promote the image of EU products and services in key niche markets, but Eurochambers asked: "What is the definition of a key niche market and who will decide which will be supported. A risk exists that one country will benefit disproportionately".
In the survey on non-tariff barriers, Eurochambers said EU companies faced problems ranging from corruption in Saudi Arabia and Mexico to bureaucracy in Switzerland, the U.S. and Israel.
"It is not unusual that European countries simply have to bribe certain officials to get through customs," the survey said.
Poor handling of goods and local transport problems were also blamed for costing EU companies dearly, while labelling laws, insurance requirements and translation of documents added to costs.

Greek companies reported a total lack of information of Albanian laws and regulations in their efforts to trade with Tirana; Spanish firms said many Argentine banks did not deserve to have their credit guarantees recognised; and Ireland complained of pedantry by Canadian officials who refused to handle invoices containing even minor typing errors.
